data.title: Hot Stocks: Alza, C
data.meta_description: Merger news and speculation lifted a number of stocks in midday trading Monday -- including pharmaceutical company Alza, C-Cube Microsystems and the World Wrestling Federation.
data.text:
NEW YORK (CNNfn) - Merger news and speculation lifted a number of stocks in midday trading Monday -- including pharmaceutical company Alza, C-Cube Microsystems and the World Wrestling Federation.

Harry Potter publisher Scholastic fell after it said it won a bid to buy eToys' inventory in a bankruptcy auction, and chipmaker PMC-Sierra fell after issuing a warning about its revenue and earnings.

Monday's winners

Alza (AZA: Research, Estimates) up $7.13 to $37.18. Drugmaker Johnson & Johnson (JNJ: Research, Estimates) is in talks to acquire Alza, which develops methods of delivering medicines to the body, for between $8 billion and $12 billion, according to reports in the Financial Times and the Wall Street Journal.

C-Cube Microsystems (CUBE: Research, Estimates) up $5.25 to $14.06. LSI Logic (LSI: Research, Estimates) has agreed to buy C-Cube, which makes equipment for digital video recording, in a stock-for-stock transaction valued at approximately $878 million.

World Wrestling Federation Entertainment (WWF: Research, Estimates) up $1.30 to $13.40. WWF, operator of WWF wrestling and XFL football, is buying its long-time rival World Championship Wrestling from CNNfn parent company AOL Time Warner (AOL: Research, Estimates).

CSFBdirect (DIR: Research, Estimates) up $1.71 to $4.21. Investment bank Credit Suisse First Boston said it would buy the balance of the outstanding shares of its online brokerage unit at a premium as flailing markets cut into the online trading business.

Cable & Wireless Optus (CWP: Research, Estimates) up $2.10 to $21.30. Singapore Telecommunications won the battle to purchase Australia's second biggest phone company, Cable & Wireless Optus, with a bid of 4.57 Australian dollars ($2.29) per share, valuing the company at 17.2 billion Australian dollars ($8.6 billion).

Edison International (EIX: Research, Estimates) up $2.30 to $13.50, PG&E (PCG: Research, Estimates) up $2.52 to $13.17. Embattled California electric utility Southern California Edison pledged Sunday to resume payments to the state's dozens of small suppliers, in the latest attempt to shore up power supplies during the current energy crisis. Also, Credit Suisse First Boston upgraded shares of Pacific Gas & Electric holding company PG&E to "buy" from "hold."

Transmeta (TMTA: Research, Estimates) up $3.25 to $19.25. The company, which makes products for mobile computers, said it is working with Microsoft (MSFT: Research, Estimates) to incorporate Transmeta's Crusoe microprocessor into Tablet PCs.

Globix (GBIX: Research, Estimates) up 44 cents to $3.44. Marc Bell, the computer services firm's chairman and CEO, exercised options to buy 55,600 shares of Globix stock and purchased $10 million of the company's senior notes.

Affymetrix (AFFX: Research, Estimates) up $3.69 to $30.44. The biotechnology company said late Friday it settled all existing litigation with Oxford Gene Technology.

PolyMedica (PLMD: Research, Estimates) up $6.88 to $23.88. The medical services company recovered from recent steep losses after saying late Friday that a Freedom of Information Act inquiry showed the company received four customer complaints in June 1999.

Vivendi (V: Research, Estimates) up $2.14 to $59.44. The entertainment conglomerate's American depositary shares rose after Gladiator, which it co-produced, won five Oscars -- including Best Picture -- Sunday night.

Immunex (IMNX: Research, Estimates) up 88 cents to $12.50. The drugmaker recovered after late Thursday announcing a major setback for potential new uses for its flagship rheumatoid arthritis drug Enbrel.

Waters (WAT: Research, Estimates) up $2.25 to $42.50. Goldman Sachs added the analystical instrument maker to its "recommended for purchase" list.

Monday's losers

Scholastic (SCHL: Research, Estimates) down $4.75 to $35.94. Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown cut its investment rating for the U.S. publisher of the Harry Potter books to "buy" from "strong buy." Scholastic also said it has conditionally won an auction for the inventory of failed Internet retailer retailer eToys (ETYS: Research, Estimates) for about $8 million.

PMC-Sierra (PMCS: Research, Estimates) down $2.37 to $31.57. The chipmaker warned about its first-quarter profit and revenue, and said it was cutting about 13 percent of its staff.

Brocade (BRCD: Research, Estimates) down $5.32 to $24.62. The chipmaker fell on the news from PMC-Sierra.

Vyyo (VYYO: Research, Estimates) down $1.44 to $2.63. The company, which supplies products for high-speed, wireless communication, said a dramatic drop-off in orders would cut first-quarter revenue to $1 million and fiscal 2001 revenue to about $20 million. In January, Vyyo projected first quarter revenue of about $7.9 million and 2001 revenue greater than $60 million.

LSI Logic (LSI: Research, Estimates) down $2.36 to $18.33. The chipmaker has agreed to buy C-Cube Microsystems (CUBE: Research, Estimates), which makes equipment for digital video recording, in a stock-for-stock transaction valued at approximately $878 million.

Micron Electronics (MUEI: Research, Estimates) down 73 cents to $2.40. The computer hardware company said Friday it is selling off its personal computer manufacturing business and will merge with an Atlanta-based Web hosting company to focus its future on that niche in the high-technology sector.

ï¿½-- from staff and wire reports
